vehicles.name: Scout Walker
vehicles.desc: Fast, lightly armed, and built to see the enemy before the enemy sees you. She carries sensor equipment that outranges her weapons and enough speed to disengage when heavier mechs arrive. The scout walker wins by reporting, not fighting.
vehicles.notes: The scout walker is your reconnaissance mech. She moves fast and spots targets for heavier units. Use her for scouting missions where the players need to map enemy positions without being caught. If she's detected, she runs — she can't survive a stand-up fight with battle mechs.

vehicles.name: Striker
vehicles.desc: A lightweight mech designed for hit-and-run attacks. She dashes in, fires a concentrated burst at a specific target, and withdraws before the enemy can bring their heavier weapons to bear. Speed is her armour.
vehicles.notes: The striker is your harassment mech. She peels off flanking shots at distracted heavies, targets damaged components, and forces the enemy to split their attention. Use her in pairs — one attacks while the other repositions. She dies to a solid hit, so she never stops moving.

vehicles.name: Medium Battlemech
vehicles.desc: The backbone of any mech force. She carries a balanced loadout of weapons and armour, fast enough to manoeuvre and tough enough to survive a few exchanges. Not the biggest, not the fastest, but always reliable.
vehicles.notes: The medium battlemech is your all-rounder and your default player mech. She does everything adequately — fire support, skirmish, assault. She's the mech that new players learn in and experienced players never entirely outgrow.

vehicles.name: Recon Quad
vehicles.desc: Four legs, low profile, and terrain-crossing ability that wheeled and tracked vehicles can't match. She scrambles over rubble, wades through swamps, and climbs slopes that would stop a biped. She sees everything and fights nothing.
vehicles.notes: The quad walker's advantage is terrain. She goes places other mechs can't — mountain passes, dense forests, ruined cities. Use her for pathfinding missions in difficult terrain. Her low silhouette makes her harder to spot, which matters when she's alone behind enemy lines.

vehicles.name: Jump Mech
vehicles.desc: Jump jets mounted on a light frame, giving her the ability to leap over obstacles, land on elevated positions, and bypass terrain that stops ground-bound mechs. She fights from rooftops, ridgelines, and anywhere else the enemy doesn't expect a mech to appear.
vehicles.notes: Jump capability changes the tactical map. She lands on buildings, leaps over walls, and engages from unexpected angles. Use her for urban combat where vertical movement matters. The fuel for jump jets is limited — count the jumps and make each one count.

vehicles.name: Fire Support Mech
vehicles.desc: Long-range missiles, indirect fire capability, and the patience to sit behind a ridgeline and rain ordnance on targets she can't even see. She fights at maximum range and relies on scouts to provide targeting data.
vehicles.notes: The fire support mech never sees the enemy directly. She fires over terrain using targeting data from scout mechs. Use her as the artillery backbone of a lance — the players in scout mechs call targets and the fire support rains destruction. Without scouts, she's blind.

vehicles.name: Command Mech
vehicles.desc: Enhanced communications, electronic warfare suite, and a command-and-control system that coordinates the entire lance. She carries less weaponry than a standard battlemech because her real value is making every other mech in the formation fight more effectively.
vehicles.notes: The command mech is your leader's ride. She provides bonuses to allied mechs in communication range — improved initiative, shared sensor data, coordinated fire. Destroying the command mech degrades the entire enemy force. Protect her or target her, depending on which side the players are on.

vehicles.name: Urban Assault Mech
vehicles.desc: Short-range weapons, heavy frontal armour, and the ability to punch through building walls. She's designed for city fighting — close quarters, restricted sightlines, and enemies around every corner. She doesn't need long range when everything is within a block.
vehicles.notes: The urban assault mech is your street-fighting specialist. Her short-range weapons are devastating at the distances urban combat provides. Use her in city scenarios where buildings channel movement and every intersection is an ambush point. She punches through walls to create her own firing lanes.

vehicles.name: Salvage Mech
vehicles.desc: Industrial manipulators, cutting tools, and a cargo bay designed to recover destroyed mech components from the battlefield. She's not a combat unit — she's the cleanup crew that arrives after the fighting and strips fallen mechs for parts that keep the rest of the force operational.
vehicles.notes: The salvage mech creates post-battle scenarios. The players escort her onto a contested battlefield to recover critical components while the enemy does the same. It's a race — who recovers the valuable tech first? She can also be pressed into emergency combat using her cutting tools as improvised weapons.

vehicles.name: Drone Controller
vehicles.desc: A light mech that carries no weapons of her own but commands a swarm of armed drones. She hides behind cover and directs her drones into the fight — spotting targets, flanking heavies, and overwhelming point defence through sheer numbers.
vehicles.notes: The drone controller changes the action economy. She controls multiple drones, each with its own attack. Use her as the enemy's force multiplier — she's hidden somewhere behind the lines, and her drones keep coming until the players find and destroy the controller. Hunting her is the real mission.
